## dplyr Package
> [Documentation](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/)

```{r dplyr}
# install.packages("dplyr") # install janitor package (remove '#' in front of install.packages("") to install)

library(dplyr) # load dplyr package
```

> ### `%>%` <- pipe 
![](pipe.png)

>Using the pipe operator `%>%` is fun and easy!<br>
<br>


```{r}
# without piping
data <- read_csv("example.csv")
data <- clean_names(data, ...)

# with piping
data <- read_csv("example.csv") %>%
  clean_names()
```

<br>
<br>

## Janitor Package
> [Documentation](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/janitor/versions/2.1.0)

```{r janitor}
# install.packages("janitor") # install janitor package (remove # in front of install.packages("") to install)

library(janitor) # load janitor package
```

> ### `clean_names()` -> returns the data frame with clean names
> This example shows the `clean_names()` function being used while reading in a '.csv' as a data frame

```{r}
data_frame <- read_csv("example.csv") %>%
  clean_names() 
```
